keyTakeAways: Ants, particularly black garden ants (Lasius niger), modify their nest architecture in response to a lethal fungal pathogen, Metarhizium brunneum.
Infected ants self-isolate, and healthy ants—especially nurses—increase their distance from foragers, demonstrating proactive social distancing.
Nests exposed to the fungus become more compartmentalized, less interconnected, with wider entrances and longer travel routes, reducing disease transmission.
These structural changes work in tandem with social behaviors to protect vulnerable colony members and limit epidemic spread.
This is the first documented case of a non-human social species actively modifying its spatial environment to combat disease.
The study provides a model for 'architectural immunity'—a concept that could inspire human designs of public spaces to reduce disease spread.

Experts such as Nathalie Stroeymeyt (University of Bristol) and Sarah Kocher (Princeton University) highlight that these ant strategies could inform future pandemic preparedness and public health planning.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study reveals that black garden ants (Lasius niger) modify both their social behavior and nest architecture in response to a deadly fungal pathogen, Metarhizium brunneum. When infected, ants self-isolate, and healthy ants—especially caregivers—move farther from high-risk foragers, demonstrating a form of proactive social distancing. Additionally, nests exposed to the pathogen become more compartmentalized, with reduced tunnel connectivity, wider entrances, and longer travel routes, which slows disease transmission. These changes work together to protect vulnerable colony members. The research, published in Science, demonstrates the first known instance of a non-human social species actively reshaping its environment to defend against disease. Experts like Nathalie Stroeymeyt and Sarah Kocher suggest these natural strategies could inspire human-designed public spaces to reduce disease spread through a concept known as 'architectural immunity'.
title: Ants Design Nests to Cut Disease Risk—A Blueprint for Human Architecture?
